David goggins canthurtme chapter 5  Chapter 5 of Can't Hurt Me: "Armored Mind"  In Chapter 5, David Goggins introduces the concept of the "Armored Mind" and the 40% Ruleâ€”the idea that when you think you're done, you're really only at 40% of your true potential.  Key Lessons from Chapter 5:  1. The 40% Rule â€“ Most people quit at 40% of their capability. The mind creates artificial limits, but you can push beyond them through discipline and mental toughness.   2. Callousing the Mind â€“ Just like hands develop calluses from hard labor, the mind gets tougher by enduring pain, discomfort, and suffering.   3. Taking Control of Your Inner Dialogue â€“ Instead of letting negative thoughts dictate your actions, you must override them with self-talk, visualization, and relentless effort.   4. Discomfort = Growth â€“ Every time you push past pain, you build a stronger, more resilient mindset.    Challenge #7: Remove the Governor  This chapter sets up Challenge #7, where Goggins tells you to push beyond the point where your mind tells you to stopâ€”whether in a workout, a race, or any area of life.  How You Can Apply This Chapter:  Next time you feel like stopping (whether in running, sobriety, or discipline), tell yourself you're only at 40% and push a little further.  Use previous wins (the Cookie Jar) as proof that you can endure.  Train yourself to get comfortable being uncomfortableâ€”because thatâ€™s where real growth happens.   Does this chapter resonate with you? Have you ever felt like you were at your limit, only to realize you had more to give?  Give me a story example of how I can apply this tactic  Applying the 40% Rule: A Sobriety Story  Letâ€™s say youâ€™re on a difficult day in your sobriety journey. The cravings hit hard, and the urge to relapse feels overwhelming. Itâ€™s one of those days where your mind is telling you, "Just one drink wonâ€™t hurt. Youâ€™ve been sober for a while now. Youâ€™ve earned it."  This is when the 40% Rule comes in: your mind is trying to stop you at 40% of your true potential, and you need to push past that point to maintain your sobriety.  How to Apply the 40% Rule in This Moment:  1. Recognize the Mindâ€™s Limits â€“ Instead of succumbing to the urge, recognize that your mind is only showing you 40% of your potential to handle the situation. The craving is temporary, but your strength is much more enduring.   2. Challenge the Thought â€“ When that voice tells you to give in, respond with, â€œIâ€™ve been here before. Iâ€™ve fought these battles, and Iâ€™ve won. This is just my mind trying to stop me. Iâ€™ve got more in me than this."   3. Get Active â€“ Change your environment. Go for a run, talk to someone who supports your sobriety, or focus on a task that requires all your energy. The key is to do something that forces you to move beyond the cravingâ€”this is where the growth happens.   4. Use Your â€œCookie Jarâ€ â€“ Remind yourself of past moments when you faced intense urges and overcame them. Think of your sober milestones, your strength, and the peace youâ€™ve gained. These wins become your armor, and each one proves to you that youâ€™re stronger than you think.   5. Push Through the Mental Block â€“ With every moment you push past your craving, youâ€™re removing that mental governor. The next time you face a similar challenge, itâ€™ll feel easier because youâ€™ve expanded your capacity.    By following this, you realize that the discomfort and urges are temporary. You are capable of far more than your mind leads you to believe in the moment.  This is a mindset that you can apply every day in your sobriety journey. Have you had moments where you felt the urge to quit, but pushed through anyway? This is exactly the kind of mental toughness Goggins talks about in Chapter 5.

First Lesson in Resilience: On SEALâ€™s first day, he challenged the speaker to do pull-ups. After the speaker struggled to complete a set, SEAL insisted that they would not leave until the speaker did 100 more pull-ups, demonstrating that people have much more capacity than they believe.  4. The 40% Rule: SEAL taught the speaker about the "40% rule," which states that when your mind tells you you're done, you're really only 40% done. This idea is central to pushing past mental limits and discovering hidden reserves of strength.  5. Embracing Discomfort: SEAL encouraged the speaker to embrace discomfort in everyday life to challenge personal limits. His motto, "If it doesnâ€™t suck, we donâ€™t do it," was designed to constantly push the speaker out of his comfort zone.  6. The Power of Will: The speaker reflects on how, even in challenging situations like marathons, people find strength beyond their initial limits. It's about applying that willpower not just in one-off events, but in daily life.

I've always used the term 'strong of mind'. I can force my body to do what I want it to do, when I want to do it, even if sometimes it's bad for my body. When my brain starts telling me I'm done, or I need to quit, or I'll do it later, I think to myself "I haven't even started yet" or "I just got here". For most people, even a minor failure, set-back, or problem is enough for them to abandon whatever it is that they are doing. Resilience to failure or misfortune through an avenue such as, although I hate to admit in my own particular case, something like "stubbornness", or some other personality trait that might be considered not desirable or negative, is actually the most beneficial part of that person's personality. Some people have it, most don't. It's the ability to not give up.

Hello, I'd like to share a personal anecdote to help those who are watching or have watched this video.   I came across this story before I got serious about physical fitness. When I eventually decided to start doing high-rep body weight movements to get into better shape, I kept this sentiment about "pushing through the pain" and achieving the end goal "at all costs" in mind.   About a year into training, I developed a wrist injury. I trained through it, doing 600 push ups every other day for a month, because I thought that's what this Navy SEAL would've done. After all, he broke his feet and almost died running his race, and all seemed to turn out fine; what's a little wrist pain?  A few months later, with the wrist injury still hanging around, I was extremely sore on a day that I was supposed to do 50 chin ups. Instead of resting, I thought of this Navy SEAL, and I knew that "he would've pushed through the pain"; so, I did too. The next day, I had rhabdomyolysis, and I was unable to train for over a week and lost significant strength and muscle mass in both arms.   Then, in easing back into training after the rhabdo, the amount of stress I was putting on the wrist injury finally hit a tipping point and I developed a serious injury, preventing me from being able to work out for months, and introducing pain into almost all of the routine tasks that were required for the cabinetry work and writing and video editing that I was doing at the time.   A couple of months later, honoring the same "grit your teeth and persevere" sentiment, I developed a knee injury and then pushed through it, working two 10 hour days doing labor-intensive, backroom work at a department store.   Today, over a year after both injuries, after more than $6000 of medical bills, and months of physical therapy for each body part, I still have two chronic injuries that significantly affect everything I do on a daily basis.  You're human, and your body knows when it needs rest. It knows when you need to stop. It knows when you're at risk of doing something really bad. If you ignore the signs your body is showing you, you're going to get seriously injured, and those injures may last the rest of your life.   I share this message because I desperately wish, in the place that I'm sitting now, that I would've read the "counterpoint" to this 40% rule when I first came across it. In certain circumstances, pushing yourself beyond your "boundaries" may make sense, and it may even be necessary. But, when it comes to your body, training, health, longevity, and your daily routine; put your health first if you're able to.

@ê§Spicy Meatballs II: The Spiceningê§‚Â  Oh yeah? How about this... Mr SEAL made Jesse Itzner do another 100 pull ups - and they weren't leaving until he did every last one. Why stop at 100? Why not 200, 500 or 1000 extra pull ups? If mental will can allow someone like SEAL to push past any 'physical' barrier then why stop running at the end of the 100 mile race? That's only the 40% mark! He could have physically continued running and therefore should have - until he had broken every bone in his body and was physically unable to continue. Also @0:37 "And during the race I kept an eye on him and around mile 70 (he weighed, probably about 260lbs which is quite large for an ultrarunner) he had broken all the small bones in both of his feet and had kidney damage"  At "mile 70" eh? The 40% rule is nonsense because it relies on an individual making subjective judgement as to where THEY think they can't go on, then using that point to assume they are really only 40% spent. I don't really like this advice, like I think a healthier way to overcome mental barriers is to just not dog on your self. Like whenever you feel incompetent or stupid it's because your missing a piece of the puzzle, not because you're not trying hard enough. You can try as hard as you want but you'll never be good if you don't put effort into the "getting better" part which is where most of your effort should be directed. Not towards trying harder when your trying to execute your knowledge. Guitar and drums taught me that. I used to think that I was just a stupid retard who was not intelligent enough to be good at those things because I tried hard, very hard. And I still never got to where I wanted because my effort was being put to the wrong place. So just remember, if you truly want to go further than you ever have before, 95% of your effort should be on learning how and 5% should actually be going there. Not 10000% maximal effort all the time.

Absolute nonsense. A man ruined his bones and gave himself organ damage for a hobby. Anyone who thinks that's somebody to take life advice from doesn't deserve a 4-minute segment on an influential channel. Of course that "40 percent rule" applies if you NEED to do something to survive and it doesn't matter if you do permanent damage to your health along the way. You can always push yourself beyond when you're "done", but in day-to-day life, common sense dictates that you STOP when you're done, so you don't completely exhaust yourself or injure yourself, so you can keep doing stuff tomorrow. There is NO REASON to go beyond that point ever in life, except in dire circumstances.  It's good to KNOW you've got something "left in the tank", but it's no good if you're constantly draining your tank to empty just because you know you haven't completely destroyed yourself yet. How long did that dude have to recover after his hobby race where he mashed his feet to paste? How is that helpful, when most people have to do shit EVERY DAY in life? It's good to know where your limits are, but having comfortable limits that keep you going EVERY DAY is just basic sanity. That man was brainwashed by the military and now his priorities are a mess and he doesn't know about self-preservation anymore.

We are capable of more than these 40% sure, but there is also a reason why the body is programmed this way.  To avoid unnecessarry injuries, and prevent constant exaustion to have lasting effects. It feels great to get past the limit, to see the results of training even pushing that limit further away, but it is as important to know the difference between "the illusion" and your actual limits.  I see a lot of comments taking sports as exemple but it goes well beyong that. Just look at how many people burn-out because "pushing forward" without a care for their mental or physical well being became their daily routine...  I used to be an artist, a crappy one but still willing to improve. I pushed forward learning multiple media, taking weird jobs, doing 10h livestreams daily to show people they can push forward...Till I got chronic pain and passed out of exaustion. My doc told me to take a break.  Which I didn't listen to (because of course I didn't) and now can't even use chopsticks on top of regularly dropping what I hold in that hand. My dexterity gone worse, meaning that I'm back at square one even tho I do have technical and theorical knowledge. Sure, I can tech, but my career as an artist is virtually over.  Always yearn to improve yourself, overcome "the illusion past when the hype dies down" but always be sure to know your limits! Wanna get past the norm? Aim for 60% if you dare but keep those last 40% to rest and recover . Don't go beyond that aside of special occurences.  Long story short: A marathon IS an event to test your limits and "go 100% for a day" but isn't ment to be a daily routine.

Last year I ran 13.5 miles without training and without taking a brake at a pretty high altitude. I've never done it before. It took me 2 1/2 hrs to get back to the starting point. Consequently I tore my lcl ligaments and had bad plantar faciitis on both legs. I was in a lot of pain. I took 3 days off work to see if my legs got better but they didn't. After my 3 days off I went straight to work. My task at work was to load and install pine trees at rich folks properties in Vail, CO. Moral of the story is that no matter how strong your mind is you still need to listen to your body bc it has a braking point. Btw I recovered two months later without seeing a Doctor or a Physical therapist. I diagnosed myself and did therapy on my own with a little bit of meditation as well.

After watching this, I'm not so sure that 40%rule is for ordinary people to heed. Engaged inÂ the sort of covertÂ military operation like the SEALS are, it puts them several notches above the opposition and enables the team to accomplish it in the face of impossible odds - and it absolutly makes sense to center the training and whole life-approach around that rule. But to most of us - it's not a sensible thing to tap into that reserve of hidden-away energy, not like that through a forced strain. It wears out the system immensily, and does not make you stronger in terms of any physical gains. Repeatedly forcing the body can eventually weaken the immunesystem and central nervoussystemÂ to a pointÂ where actual sickness, both acutely and chronically can easily take hold to invalidating degree at a much earlier point in life than would otherwise be the case. If what you're doing requirer you to survive at all costs to accomplish, like a soldier, then it doesn't matter if you pay for this outburst of excessive energy in the moment with a couple of years in the senior-end of your life. But if you're an ordinary person like most are, there are other methods of mastering this hidden energy-reserve and which rewards as huge mental benefits as the 40% rule, as well asÂ they reward actual physical betterment of the system in it's entirety. These methods, although different in different places and different traditions have all in common that they have been taught for thousands of years, are well established and greatly revered by thoseÂ who practice them.

Good, interesting video. Although more telling here, in my opinion, is the person talking. If you want to succeed, take note of what he's doing. People like him are always looking for ways to improve, to learn from others, and keep moving forward, recognizing the shapes in their lives that hold them back ("I was in a rut"). He's highly sensitive to the changes in his "everyday", and looks to improve the ways he does things. If you wonder why people succeed, it's not because they got lucky and met a person who gave them some hidden secret to life. No, these self-made people have the attitude of seeing what's holding them back, being capable of looking at their being from the outside, without bias. That's one of the reasons why some people just succeed, but getting that attitude and being capable of looking at yourself like that are the real challenge. Not finding a Navy Seal lol

He claims in the video that the marathon runner had â€œbroken all the small bones in his feet.â€ Approximately 25 % of the 206 bones in an adult maleâ€™s body are in his feet. (52 bones in both feet). This is because there are a LOT of small bones in the feet. NO ONE breaks ALL the small bones in their feet, under any circumstance, (short of jumping in a woodchipper), and certainly; no one is continuing to run marathons afterwards if they did manage to. It is possible to break a couple of these small bones and continue to run on sheer adrenaline for a while, but it would be extremely foolish to persist in worsening the already significant damage for stubborn pride. Thankfully, this story is complete bullshit, with zero basis in facts or reality, anyway...

This is the survivorship bias fallacy. Special forces are heavily screened both mentally and physically to achieve this result in the first place. The end result is a small pool of individuals who fit the 40% rule. If it was this easy, why the fail rate and medical screenings?  It's like taking a pool of nobel prize physicists and saying that everyone can do calculus if they just try harder since the sample pool discovered that math is easy for them.

This discussion, reminds me of the idea of having to reinvent yourself with the biggest hurdle being how we think about everything. For me this happened on ajungle trek that was overloaded with physical, emotional and psychological challenges. My friends back home who knew better, thought l had a death wish (interesting term, makes you wonder whether you have to almost meet death to live well). In the washup l had a nervous break down right there in the jungle. I was done, l was prepared to curl up and meet my death. Some how l pushed through and continued on against even more setbacks. When l looked back on that experience, once home, as l didn't know at the time what was happening or what would become of me, l was just experiencing it after all, l realised that l had unshakedled my brain of a whole range of negative - l can't  do this - type of thinking and had entered a different phase of life. In most ways now, l am a can do person, as it relates to me personally, but am not an optimist because my life involves others and many of them are children, who may never have a chance to be broken in spirit and in mind, then remade like l was, because they are molly-codalled. I woke up one night and it felt like my hands were on fire. I stuck my hands in the ice trough in the freezer and it did nothing. The pain wouldnâ€™t stop and I was in tears. I had to take muscle relaxers to calm them. Moral of the story....donâ€™t go overkill and push too much past your limit. Listen to your body. Once upon a time I did about 80 pull ups and 100 pushups every day. That used to be my daily workout. Then after a 6 month long of a complete break from the gym, I barely managed to reach upto 30 pull ups in my daily workout and had decided to take it slowly, climbing the mountain 1 inch at a time.  And then I saw this video. I took upon the challenge that the SEAL put up to Itzler and head straight to the gym.  I didn't hit the count of 100 but I nailed 80 pull ups, 50 push ups and 50 tricep dips, all of this in about 50 min at the gym. I never saw myself meeting this goal any time in the next 6 months on my own.  I see so many people out here making fun of the Seal and his accomplishments. Our history is full of stories where people have accomplished the unthinkable against the greatest odds. It shouldn't be so hard to believe that the man completed the marathon under the said circumstances. Show some respect people. He has earned it.  Thank you Itzler, and thank you Seal David Goggins, for sharing this video and your stories.  If I get a chance, I surely would like to invite him over to my house to live with me.

You CAN go on beyond that 40%, but should you... The rule is probably quite accurate. You can do more than your body thinks and without getting injured. You can use probably about 2/3 of the "tank" relatively safely, but after that 40% mark the likelihood of getting injured starts to go up fast. It's like with stress: a little can be good for you, but prolonged exposure is really really bad. The reserve is  there for life and death situations, so when vital organs like kidneys start to shut down, it is extremely stupid go on unless you really are in life and death situation.

A little context is needed here. A Navy Seal is trained for war, making life & death decisions & pushing physical & mental limits for the purpose of accomplishing a military objective as well as survival. Yes, we can learn a lot from pushing those limits. Should we always run out and be constantly pushing those limits? It depends. One needs to have perspective and understand the cosequences of pushing those limits. Things like injuries, recovery, mental health, well being, relationship consequences, impact on career and family. You got to pick your battles (pun intended). Not every endeavor is worth a life or death struggle of herculean effort.

Nivola - it's true.  I ran many marathons and I always hit the wall around miles 19 or 20.  It's like the worst pain ever and your legs tell you that they are so tired the cannot go another step.  But once I make it to miles 25 then suddenly my body perked up and it's like a walk in the park.  Why?  Because your body always want to reserve some energy and it will signal you early to stop.  But once it realized that it has only 1.2 miles left then it's said "well, ok, we know you're going to be ok"  let me release the rest of the energy and let you finish the damn 1.2 miles.  There are many studies that proved this.  I'm sure you can google them if you're interested.  I'm sure that over decades with so many hell week Seal Training that the instructors over time figured out what the human potential is.  Their estimation of 40% seemed correct.  You only know this when you push yourself past this limit and pain.

I had a similar experience. I saw a Seal swimming at the pool. He would disappear underwater for a good 10 minutes! He swam like a fish! My wife said that we should go talk to him. At first, he was standoffish, but finally, he started talking to my wife. She looked him up on facebook on the way home and he seemed very impressive.  Apparently, she decided to cold call him for me, because I came home from work and found him in my living room, the next week. This time, he was really talkative. I invited him to eat, and he laughed and said that he was starving! He ate nearly a whole bucket of KFC chicken, a container of mashed potatoes w/ gravy, and two pieces of Hershey pie.  We became instant friends and even my wife loved having him over. He was super loyal. I travel for work, and he would always tell me not to worry because he would take care of my wife while I was gone. Once, I came home early from a trip and found him sitting in a folding chair, with a bottle of water, eating a cherry toaster strudel and wearing a rob! I was terrified! I hate to say it, but I thought the worst. It turns out that my wife had a heard a noise the night before and he came over because she was scared. Lol  He was always positive and encouraging. He told us about the 40% rule and then said, if you want something, then take it! It really helped us. My wife started dressing better and taking care of herself. She would go to the gym 3 or 4 times a week for hours. It was great to see her so happy and looking good.  One night, I shared something very personal with the Seal. I admitted that we had been trying, unsuccessfully, to have a child for years. He told me that it was a mental block. He told me a few unusual things that I could try with my wife. To my surprise, she loved them. He said that I should always tell her, "If it doesn't suck then I don't do it!", so that she would give me oral pleasure. He said that I had to "know" that she would get pregnant. 40% wouldn't cut it! Then, he leaned over, looked at me with a 1,000 yard stare and said that he "knew"  she would be pregnant soon. He walked away without another word.  When I came home the next day, he was at my house. He walked out and met me at the car and looked at me again with that crazy look and said the same thing before he left. He had stopped by, just to encourage me! Everyday, when I got home it was the same thing. He was always there just to tell me that he knew she would be pregnant. It was amazing.  Sure enough, he was right! When I found out, he was the first person that I called. He answered the phone in his normal way, "Hoo Yah!" and then sat silently. I told him the good news but he was silent. He just hung up. I guess he got shipped out, because we never saw him again.  My wife wanted to name our son after him, but we realized that we didn't know his name! We had always called him Seal! My son, now 15, is the strongest kid in his school and captain of the swim team. I honestly believe that he wouldn't be here today, if Seal hadn't came along to help us.  That has been many years ago, but my wife still talks about Seal almost everyday.

Â @alinatahir6476Â  If you're a fan of ridiculously long comments, then here's another that I posted about the time I met Ted Nugent.  I met Ted several years ago. My wife became friends with his wife and they came over for dinner once. I had heard his music, but didn't know much about him. They arrived with a bottle of wine in hand. He was a really nice guy and we hit it off from the start. He had lots of great stories, a really warm demeanor and a funny laugh.    When we sat down for dinner, he started dishing meat on his plate. I said try some of my wife's brussels sprouts, but he said that he only ate meat. When he finished getting his food, there was almost no beef left. He had about 4 lbs of meat and he ate every bite. After dinner, my wife let our long haired Chihuahua out to visit. Ted picked up the tiny dog and held her gently, as he asked my wife the dogs name. She responded, "That's miss ChaCha". Ted laughed and stroked her fur as be baby talked her. It was funny to see him being so child like. We continued to drink and talk as Miss ChaCha went about her normal business, but she stayed close to Ted and eventually went to sleep next to his boot.  Then, Miss ChaCha woke up and got on the sofa next to Ted. He started petting her again as he talked to us. He kept saying that she was a beautiful little girl.    As they were leaving, Ted picked up Miss ChaCha and held her lovingly against his neck. I said, "She really like you!", as she softly licked his face. He smiled and held her close and said that she had a beautiful soul. She looked like she went into a trance as he held her. He gave her a gentle kiss on the head and carefully laid her on a pillow on the sofa. I reached over to pet her and Ted looked at me with a crazy but gentle smile and softly whispered, "She's free now". At first I thought he was joking and I started to laugh but then I realized that he had killed our dog with his hands!   He looked at me with a level of intensity that I have never seen, while still smiling, and said, "Thank you". My wife, in disbelief, picked up Miss ChaCha and started to cry. Ted gently put his hand on my wife's back and said, "She's mine now". All I could think was, oh shit! This crazy bastard just killed our Chihuahua and now he's going to take my wife. I tried to avoid eye contact as I said, "Go easy Ted. I'm married to her". For a second, he looked confused but then he smiled and started to laugh as he placed his hand firmly on my back.    He gently took Miss ChaCha's limp body from my wife's shaking hands. It was then that I realized that he had no intentions of taking my wife. I'll never forget the look of innocence and joy on his face as he said, "Love transcends death". Then he paused and sang the same words.  Neither my wife or I said a word. As he started out the door, still holding Miss ChaCha, he leaned over, kissed my wife's cheek and said, "thank you for the beautiful trophy".

Hate to be a stickler here but "the wall" is not a mental thing at all. It's just a physiological change-over from burning glycogen for energy to burning fat for energy. Takes the body a little but to start using fat once the glycogen stores are depleted, and also for most people this is, or at least feels, less efficient - hence less energy, and the lapse seeming like a "wall" of exhaustion. I get the point... but lets not confuse biology with mental fortitude.

Â weejamsÂ  the Navy has only two required weigh-ins. Twice a year and it has nothing to do with performance but with health and the cost of obesity. Naval Special Warfare does not do anything more, then then Naval requirement for weight. Unless you are attending military free fall or conducting parachute operations, then you are not being weighted. Running long distance, has nothing to do with being fast. If you run a 8 min mile, you are only running forty yards every 10 to 15 seconds. That is not fast. If individuals need to be fast, then they have to generate power. To generate power, the individual must use speed and strength. This why, Naval Special Warfare, introduces SEAL and SWCC candidates to powerlifting during the NSW Prep course. Then NSW spend 3.2 million a year, funding the human performance at every command. They focus on developing power, through power lifting. No, they do not weight 300 pounds. They do on average carry more muscle, then anyother branch of service or other special operations team. It's not uncommon, to see a guy walking around at 225 to 260 pounds and hold 10 to 12 percent body fat. You have to fast, take punishment and  deliver punishment. Individuals look more like a strong safety or rugby player and not runners or swimmers.

Â weejamsÂ  there's a lot more then just surf torture. Try running the mile from the barracks to the pool, then swimming for three hours. Then running a mile to the beach, then doing pullups and dips for an hour. Then run the five miles from the beach to the demo pits and back. Then run the o-course five times for time. Then you have surf passage, for the next hour or two. Then log PT for an hour or two. On Fridays you either run the 10 miles to the North Island gate or 15 miles to the elephant cages and back. In-between that, you eat and if there's down time, they punish you. The run to and from the galley is two miles. That's six miles, of running, just to eat your food. I think a lot of people are aware they have a lot more in them when they give up. Most people would stop doing pull ups when their arms hurt so much they cant do anymore, because they realise that is your body telling you that if you continue you are likley to do damage. Can you continue through the pain barrier, yep sure. Should you, that is where your interlect should kick in and say hang on a second let me weigh up the pros and cons of this situation. Do I want to lose the use of my arms for the next few days just to prove to this guy im not a wimp. The more inteligent person would realise they dont have to prove anything to anyone. Im sure the guy that continued running with broken toes feels really tough. He probably eitehr gets a kick out of impressing others or just enjoys pushing his limits for its own sake. Personally Id rather not break all my toes in the first place, but if I did I wouldnt grind up the bits just to prove how tough i was. Combat situations are completely different as giving up = death. I probably agree with the fact that our minds give up before our bodies are truly done, but I disagree with the reasoning behind hitting "the wall" and pushing through it. Hitting the wall generally occurs when your body finishes burning through the immediately available glucose and you become suddenly hypoglycemic (anyone who know the feeling of "bonking" knows the feeling of hypoglycemia - shaky, sweaty, lightheaded, nauseated, etc). The "second wind" is just your liver beginning to mobilize glycogen, which can then act as a fast-metabolizing source of more glucose.

Your video inspired me to write the following commentâ€¦  Never stop pushing your body and mind to the limits of what other people are willing to watch you subject yourself to and you will be standing, running, lifting (etc.) more than most people. I'm overweight but yet I can push harder (endurance) than all of my friends/family/etc., why? Because I know that mentally I can push my physically weaker body harder/longer than a weaker-minded person can push their strong bodies.   There's at least four key aspects to true strength (IMHO):  â€¢ Mental Strength: To me this is someoneâ€™s capability to keep trying until they achieve their goal no matter what ("the master has failed many more times than the novice has ever tried"). For example, I had the mental will power to stop smoking cold turkey after many years of smoking 1-2 packs a day. I didn't plan it and I didn't think about it before I committed. I just made up my mind to do so, and I did (for my health).  â€¢ Mental tolerance: Most people will not subject them self to something they physically/mentally canâ€™t stand/tolerate (â€œkeep your friends close and you enemies closerâ€). Most people will start to feel physical pain and metal suffering if they try to but some people like the people who walk/run across hot coals can and do have exceptional mental tolerance for things others would say is not possible. For example, I intentionally subjected myself to things I could not normally tolerate (ice water swimming, running in -40c, long distance bike riding in 45c heat, pushing on with a broken bone, etc.) to build up my mental tolerance to the unbearable.  â€¢ Physical Strength: We all know this one so no explanation/interpretation is needed. For example, I recently had to do a stress test for my heart at the hospital and I was worried because the doctor told me not to stop until I couldn't physically go anymore. I pushed my body so hard that the doctor was forced to terminate the stress test once I hit a sustained 220 BPM. I simply never gave up mentally or physically because I never planned to. I could have kept on going until I passed out.   â€¢ Physical tolerance: Each personâ€™s physical tolerance is different and I think of it like an immune system that can be improved with proper training/practice (like people who run marathons/triathlons or hold their breath for extended amount of time underwater). For example, I once knew a kick boxer who would break 2x4's and eventually cinder blocks with his shin to build up his physical tolerance for hard kicks to the shin. It's key to be able to tolerate any and all aches & pain in order to keep pushing on when others would stop. I would regularly push my body to the point where Iâ€™ll pass out or vomit and over time my bodyâ€™s tolerance/endurance increased and eventually this limit was harder and harder to reach.  My trick is to put my mind in a state of mental Zen (a happy place if you will) combined with a physical tempo/beat/rhythm (heart rate, breathing rate, and movement rate need to have a synchronicity). Another thing that sets me apart from most is the fact that I only believe in myself. Call it selfish or egotistical but I truly believe that anything I put my mind to I can do if I try my hardest and never EVER give up within reason of course (I canâ€™t win the lottery no matter how hard I try at it). The only time I make an exception is for loved ones out of respect and understanding that they have a sincere concern for my personal health/well-being. Many people at gymâ€™s have warned me that my method is a very unhealthy practice so Iâ€™ve been on a permanent hiatus from gym (when someone gives you sound advice you take it). Iâ€™m far from perfect but I always gave/give my all.  Disclaimer: Please do not try what Iâ€™ve mentioned above as it could put your body/mind at serious risk of permanent harm or even death. For example, when I was young (16-18) I thought I could build my tolerance to the cold but once you get frostbite youâ€™re more susceptible the having frostbite again and again. So itâ€™s important to keep in mind that the body canâ€™t build tolerance to everything. Also, proper techniques & training by a professional and medical advice from a doctor is always essential/necessary before trying to expand your â€œtrue strengthâ€. Be safe not foolish!  Thanks for the inspirational video!

Marathon or any other endurance event - you must operate within your aerobic capacity especially in the first 30 minutes (varies by training background and recent diet).  If you are burning anaerobically, you will bonk as the carbs flame-out (fat doesn't burn well anaerobically), which makes you feel awful and get the strong urge to quit. The general concept is staying within a range o percentage of VO2-max. Not well versed in anti-quit cheats for weight exercises (pull ups are a gravity weight exercise) though if you are already able to handle the weight very well, then the pace regulation techniques may still work.   I think if you splice the science and monitoring used in professional sports (soccer especially) with the mental toughness already in military training, you can maximize the gains without overdoing it   (breaking all the foot bones and frying the kidneys - likely from severe dehydration and electrolyte depletion - might have pre-existing damage from uncontrolled diabetes also).  All the monitoring they do in professional sports is to adjust the work levels of the players.  Some are under-efforting, but most are over-exerting, over-efforting and going over the ideal performance-growth VO2-max percentage range.  Soccer is not as straightforward as cycling or rowing though as soccer needs a lot of sprint burts.  Though i think it was nerfed, but I think the US water polo team did fairly well in mock seal training.  Their bodies are pre-conditioned for cold water though and water polo is a low-fame high-determination sport. I don't think the US national soccer team will do nearly as well.    High school sports going hard to weed out the quitters is not that dangerous barring drug use or severe diet/hydration problems.   Elite sports and military, going hard to weed out the quitters without vitals and other monitoring (all that magic computer stuff about every pro coach on the team uses nowadays) can be dangerous - seal candidates getting stress fractures that slowly grow into full-on fractures and keep on going...   (think after the halway point of hell week, almost all drop-outs are medical force-outs) Not sure if any died during training, but performance enhancing substance use is on the rise in the military.  Most sudden cardiac deaths are from abuse of such substances, or from prescription drugs (often legit), or the interaction or side-effect compounding of multiple drugs/supplements.

My attitude was adopted from the Monty Python group - Ah, tis but a flesh wound. Every time they asked me for 10, I gave 12. When they asked for 5 minutes, I gave it 6. I never stopped. OK, listen carefully. "When he was done he had broken bones in his feet and KIDNEY damage." At the end of this guy's "100 pullups" he couldn't move his arms for a week and probably had a partial rotator cuff tear, or some tissue damage.   My big rule? Consistency, then frequency. Forget intensity and duration - at first. Second? Don't get injured (unnecessarily).  You FIND your wall breaking experience, you don't beat it into yourself. Why? Look at all the tough guy military people who, after the gruel-a-thon of service who lose it all and get fat and sick and prematurely old. Speak to them. Talk about keeping tracking record, nutrition, how you get out the door that day.  Find something you can be passionate about and get out there 7 days a week, >350 days a year, 5 years in a row. That's what I did. Combo of non-weight bearing stuff and weight machines and going through the 5 training zones; active recovery and biphasic sleep.

"the wall" in a marathon is actually  a real limit on how much time you can go for an extended period of time. It's the time when your muscles cannot do any more strenuous activity,  so you have to slow down to a pace that you can hold for significantly longer. You've  long passed the 40% have to push yourself threshold. For example, my dad did a marathon at 17 years old,  and he got roughly 3 hours and 3 minutes. However,  at 2 hours 15, he was on pace to run under 2 hours 50. He didn't get slower because he gave up,  he got slower because his cells couldn't carry out cellular respiration fast enough to hold the pace he was going any longer.  Elites don't hit the wall because their race ends before the wall happens.
Working at keeping on top of life, and understanding the 40% rule.  Very stimulating emotionally.

1. Watch David Goggins on Joe Roganâ€™s podcast. Heâ€™s the Seal in this story.   He talks about feeling like a failure in life, weighing 300 lbs, and using your pain as motivation.  2. This guy isnâ€™t explaining the mindset well at all, in my opinion. The point is that you can train yourself to identify doubt, and condition your mind to push way beyond that point.  We tell ourselves what we can do. We allow ourselves to quit. We put these stories up in our mind that limit what weâ€™re capable of. If you feel like quitting, throw more on top of it to kill those thoughts. You can learn to overcome.  â€Failure is not an optionâ€ is bullshit. Failure is always an option. Itâ€™s the only option in life.   You need to learn to identify when youâ€™re quitting or looking for an out. You need to train yourself to identify that, and immediately react to it.  Use that mindset next time you go for a run. Doing a short run to get ready for a 5k? â€” Make it a 5k. Do 10k. When that doubt enters your mind, put that option out of reach.  If thereâ€™s anything you donâ€™t want to do, You need to do that. Your mind is telling you exactly what you need.  Jordan Peterson sometimes touches on the same points in regards to having a â€˜callingâ€™ in life. That can be a curse, because if you donâ€™t answer your inner judge, it can literally kill you. You have to overcome fear in life, constantly.  If you let your fears and anxieties hold you back, they will destroy you. Your life will be filled with depression and regret. You need to fight that. You need to fight through that.  There is some fucked up shit youâ€™ve locked away in your mind. Shit that we donâ€™t want to confront. You need to go in those dark places and slug it out with some demons. Theyâ€™ll eat you alive if you donâ€™t.  Thatâ€™s not a fight we pick. Shit haunts us. Those demons pick us. You donâ€™t have a choice but to go through them, and you canâ€™t put it off. Itâ€™s terrifying and daunting but you donâ€™t have a choice. Either you do it, or you let your doubt destroy you.  The problem is, the reluctant man is driven to action, only when the pain of inaction eclipses the pain of action.  This isnâ€™t short term motivation. This is conditioning your mind over and over to get through things that suck.

I learned something similar in the Army. Pain is weakness leaving the body. I entered basic as a weakling. My stats were laughable. I thought I made a big mistake. But I learned to embrace discomfort and pain and draw power from my will to work through it. When my body wanted me to stop I consciously fought that urge, often an overwhelming feeling of inevitable limits, and found I had a LOT more to give. Even when I reached what we call muscle failure, where I thought I physically just couldn't do more, I started realizing that this was a safety limit for my body that was too conservative. I never got stronger until I learned to dominate these instinctive urges to stop and push through them. Then I started getting better really quickly, meeting the standards in a few weeks and finally exceeding them by a bit. For a guy that couldn't do 7 push-ups going in, and certainly someone that hated athletics (still do), it was enlightening to realize my body could do what I wanted even when all the signals it is sending my brain would have previously discouraged me from even trying to break that wall.

Essentially. Look at how animals in general evolved: eat, reproduce, survive. Anything that doesn't help with that is tosses aside and abandoned. Consider humans: we are mammals of the hominid genus, therefore we are great apes in the broader family of monkeys (to put EXTREMELY simply). Humans spend the majority of our time indoors, in cool temperatures, sitting down; minimal energy expenditures. At the end of the day we want to be wealthy both financially and nutritionally. This means that we want to do as little as possible to get the maximum of sustenance to facilitate survival, nutritional gain, and as many reproduction opportunities as possible( though some of use will deny that). Our minds are wired to get the maximum payout with as little energy as possible. In a marathon situation, that mindset is being put to the test. We are putting ourselves in such a huge energy deficit that our minds are telling us, from a GENETIC LEVEL, to just FUCKING STOP and rest or otherwise end energy expenditure. It is only when we tell our self no that we really see how our higher level mental processing helps us. We can tell our unconscious, animal-istic self to shut the hell up an let us get on with whatever we want to do. Lower order animals can't actively do that outside of life or death situations.  Many of us have this ability, but rarely do we use it. Even then, only those who actively put themselves in these situations, such as soldiers or athletes, can really claim mastery over it. People in war torn parts of our world can also claim that they master it, due to the extreme nature of where they live and the necessity to overcome what their unconscious mind is telling them to survive. However, people in industrialized and post-industrialized nations dont have many in their population that can claim they have what it takes to get through these types of situations and mean it.

Year late, but: In the literal sense, as in the story given, our muscles can do a LOT more than they normally do, mostly for strength, but also somewhat endurance. However, forcing yourself past that limit usually causes (semi) permanent tissue damage as your muscle basically tears itself apart, so your mind isn't being lazy, it wants you to not cripple yourself over a footrace.

Frank Â And you don't even find it Ironic that the real circle-jerk here is the people defending a quick fix soloution to the problem of hard work. They've probably put no real focused effort into anything in their lives, and now a video is selling them a "secret". Meanwhile, all the other people out there who can do "incredible" things are out there just DOING them and not finding them a huge mental barrier to overcome. They have a word for this"wall". It's the same one we all use: "Discomfort". nothing more. How much money did you pay into this scam? Sounds like buyers remorse to me. I'm not saying people can't run 100 miles. People do it all the time, and there's nothing remarkable about a time of 19 hours. And guess what...the ones who train to do it, do it. And a guy off the street can't do it. There is literally nothing his brain can do to alter that fact. There is no "secret". It's a damn sorry state of affairs when a bit of hard work is such a mystery to so many people, that people can sell mystical mental bullshit. Training to run 100 miles is hard. Sitting cross legged and going "Ommmm" is easy. Sparring for long periods is hard. Trying to develop "chi" is easy (Physically easy anyway, since it doesn't exist) Â If you're watching this video intending to improve yourself, then you're clearly just that type of person that keeps falling for this sort of stuff. There's no secret. Some shit is damn uncomfortable. Deal with it, or don't do that shit. There's the "secret" completely free of charge. This works well for physical feats apparently, but does it actually work for your brain ? Because your brain isn't a muscle and you can't train it as such. (Despite what a lot of "advice givers" will tell you..) Because when my brain tells me I can't fuckin study anymore, I can push myself, but I won't learn anything, it's not efficient. And I don't need physical advice, I run Semi-Iron Mans and the only reason I don't run the full one is because I'm too slow on the marathon so I wouldn't finish before the 17h.. I could "push myself" but I won't make it under 17h. Fact. So I should train more, well yes maybe, but I don't have the time so no. And it's bullshit anyway, say your brain tells you "I'm done" on km 21, and you push to km 42: let's say you're a bit used to it and your brain quits at 50%; is it linear ? Because if it is you're done at 42km. But that means the 40% rule is false at that point ? 40% rule is stupid, it suggests it's like a Poisson distribution.. So your brain tells you you're done at 42km but it's actually 50% so you can run another 42km, then you get to 84km and your brain tells you this time I'm done, but it's actually 50% so you can run another 84km. No you can't. You can't keep on going for ever.

Overall, I agree with Duckman1616 but to give the seal the benefit of the doubt - he may not have realized at the time that the pain in his feet was due to broken bones and also it is likely that the kidney damage was not permanent. It is fairly common for people who really push themselves running to have some degree of Rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown) after the run. If this is significant, then it will impair your kidney function for a few hours - less if you drink enough water. If you really, really overdid it you might have some residual permanent damage but the greater risk is the blood chemistry derangement which happens temporarily while your kidneys aren't working properly. It can sometimes bring on heart arrhythmias.

While the human body is amazing and can overcome many things, there ARE limits where you can't go back. I spent 8 years in a wheelchair, much of that time bed ridden not even able to have sheets on my legs because of the unbearable pain rated on a pain scale as worse than the amputation of digits, childbirth, cancer, and phantom limb pain, and I now do physical labor on a daily basis and I'm studying to be a physical therapist. A practical example to show that you're both right is an adrenaline rush. Normally your brain caps you at a certain muscle activation level, which happens to be around 40% with some training. When adrenaline hits your brain, that cap is removed, because it's now in survival mode, and injury is preferable to death. Plus it has more neurons to do recruitment, so it's actually physically possible, at the cost of cognitive power.

That pull up story is bullshit. After reaching your peak you can't just regenerate muscle tissue and energy instantly especially while you're hanging from the bar the whole time. The only way I could see that KIND OF be a possibility is if someone lit a fire under his ass while he did it. The adrenaline rush alone would probably give him 1-2 more at MOST.

Just to clear this up, the pull up story isn't bullshit. He never said he was hanging from the bar firstly. Secondly, your ATP-PC (to put simply your fast, explosive energy) system does restore very quickly but won't provide long term energy. It won't let him repeatedly do sets of eight or 10, but one pull up then 30 seconds rest, then one more pull up? No problem. Try it yourself.

Thing is you will end up ripping your muscles apart, you may have the energy for it but structual fatigue takes its toll. Thing is once a month this isnt an issue. Do this weekly or daily and you are setting yourself up for permanent damage, tendinitis. etc. Its a way to train the will, just dont train your will beyond what is healthy for you. Slow and steady progression means peaking later, but that peak lasts longer and wont leave you with injuries ad you will fall less from your peak.

MsMi321 That's only if you try to do it all at once. You can do 100 pushups in an hour, or 100 all at once. Guess which one isn't going to tear your muscles up? Your body recovers very quickly when doing things over a long period of time.

Terra Estrahl thing is, 100 push ups and lets say you can only do 10. No matter how long you take to do those push ups it will destroy your musvles, less than doing them all at once. but still the damage is dealt.  This is what stractual fatigue is, that if I take say a thin metal straw and bend it enough times, NOTE the amount is important here not the intensity, then the straw will eventually break.   Our muscles are made of collagen fibers, and thin and thick fillaments namely myosin and actin. These bands exert tremendous amounts of force on each other when they contract aka the power stroke (Where myosin grabs the actin and pulls the Z lines towards each other ZZline being the ends of the sarcomere or for simplicities sake lets call it the mechanical unit).  Contracting them too many times over a period of time where there is relatively constant exertion wil lead to tears, breakage and is in general just classified as overusage. But as I said doing this once a month is fine, as your body has 29 more days to recover as well as develop from this. Our bodies do not really recover directly after excercise, we do most of our recovery during sleep, hence why many athletes must get enough sleep in order to function at any sort of competetive level. As melatonin is released and the body begins its essentially ritualistic repair cycle.   AKA: Medically speaking this advice of goign so far above your max that its going to ruin you for the day or even week is bad advice if done daily. One should be able to do at least half of their goal for this sort of exersion to at least be able to recover in time to get back to normal training without causing injury if they are going to apply this.   ALSO NOTE: there seems to be this utter musconception that training hard and suffering is a good thing when in fact the body needs to slowly adjust to whats happening. The slower the adjustment often times it seems the beter, as the body then is able to handle the load much more effectively as all necessary adaptations have occured as well as the fact that the person is used to the load being exertedon their mind, body and nervous system. (Yes this system is also at risk in overexertion)

It's not just that. If you constantly push your body for 100%, you will do some serious damage, particularly over time. There is a reason why many military units, have age restrictions. The Foreign Legion doesnt accept people over 35. There is only so much you can squeze out of people, before the joints, muscles and bones give up on them. If you want to get old AND capable of moving without pain, you better work with the limits of your body, rather then always giving 100%. Once you're joint is seriously fucked up, you can't just replace it like a flat tire.

So many things wrong with this video and and it's quite annoying that it's misleading and misinforming so many people on the level of mental/physical fortitude SEALs and the particular SEAL Jesse is talking about display. So let this be the comment that ends all stupid comments.   First of all, the man Jesse is referring to in the video as "seal" is Navy SEAL David Goggins. He is a civilian now and was a civilian at the time this video was released, so it really doesn't make much sense at to why he keeps referring to him as "seal". It's not only misleading but quite annoying.  Second, the race that Jesse and David ran in where he broke the bones in his feet/had kidney failure was a 100 mile race; a race that is intended to be broken up by multiple people. David ran the entire race by himself. This is why he experienced some adverse effects.  Third, to those of you saying David is "stupid" for not listening to his body when he had kidney failure and broke the bones in his feet, this is EXACTLY what's supposed to happen in these type of races (also known as "ultramarathons"). Many of you have also stated that David will have "permanent health problems" following this and this makes him stupid, when this couldn't be farther from the truth. Kidney failure (despite what it sounds like) is something that heals relatively quickly (if treated correctly) and does not leave permanent effects.  Fourth, to those of you questioning David's credibility and saying that he's "stupid" and "doesn't know what he's talking about" since he split his kidney in a race, David has been running ultramarathons for 10+ years, was a Navy SEAL, runs 100+ miles a week, and has written multiple award-winning books on running, endurance, nutrition, etc. The fact that you think you know more than him (considering he is practically the father of ultra long distance running) is absolutely laughable. It's like a 9 year old who just watched Bill Nye for the first time lecturing a 65 year old Harvard professor who's focus is general relativity on why the Earth is flat.

I get the point of the video, it says we are more capable than we think, we should all be inspired to do great things, point taken, but putting one's body at risk in some unnecessary situations can be harmful, even life threatening at times. When you're running in a hot weather and your body is so under stress that you can hear your heart beat in your ears, take a break and cool down your body, you don't wanna die from heat stroke just because you want to endure a little longer for bragging rights. Under life or death situation, human body is capable of unimaginable things but that should not mean you should push to that limit in everyday activities. There is a limit for a reason, to preserve oneself. Every problem has a more rational and smart way to approach it. I do see the value of hardship and training soldiers put themselves through to prepare them for every situation; but for a common Joe, simple regular exercise everyday and focusing on the mental and skill development would be far more  better path. I hope no one goes to break their bones after watching this video, because that is not the point this video is trying to make.

What a load of bullshit.   Your brain saying that you're done is when you're done. Sure you can go on, but from there on out you pay for it with your health. This can be physical health, like the seal who ended the run with kidney damage and broken bones. Or it could me mental damage in the shape of a burn-out depression. Why is everyone talking crap about a NAVY SEAL? Believe it or not they are some of the most intelligent and well put together military on the planet. What he's talking about is how they have to approach a combative situation, and how having some mental fortitude can better your life. I.E. Not to give up because something seems like it's too difficult to be worth it.

Alternative angle: most marathon runners burn out several miles before the finish line because most marathon runners seriously under-prepare for the race, but then run it anyway because they want to be able to brag about having run a marathon.  Don't look at it as going the extra 60% beyond your limits, but rather as having been 60% lazy.  There are lots of runners who regularly run significantly longer than marathon distances. For fun, not as professionals.

I think the main purpose was just to show that most of us are capable of more than what we're doing. You don't have to be a Navy SEAL, you just should know that what you're doing right now isn't what your full potential is, most likely.

You both have good points.   It is worth it to watch the video and make you own decisions, but overall I think that awareness of your own limits, not your habits, but actual limits beyond which you would cause damage, is discouraged in favor of taking more robotic options. It is not that robots will steal jobs, but rather, being robotic is now seen as superior to being a human, and being smart, and saying no to some things.   Preparing for a marathon and running it is a great hobby; but organizing a marathon and profiting financially from it is smarter. You could even do both.   Smarter, also, is using your time to work out how to afford a car, or bicycle.   Less impressive to those who worship sacrifice, but I think in order to really use our full potential, we have to use what we have to get what we want, rather than abuse ourselves to get what might impress some, might inspire some, but hurts ourselves in the process -- unnecessarily.   Addictions come in all forms, and addiction to goal achievement hides two related, but harder (mentally, emotionally) skills: goal-setting (choosing the right goals for you) and renegotiation (altering a plan when circumstances change), both parts of integrity.  It is not how hard (sacrificial) the goal is, that should matter, but rather, what it means to you, and how it helps your own fulfillment.

Why would you take advice from a guy who broke all the bones in his feet and gave himself kidney damage trying to run a relay race by himself?  He sounds like an idiot.  That's how you fuck up your body, completely ignoring moderation.

Yes, we all have that will, but we shouldn't always execute it when it's not necessary. That will is there for when you're in life or death situations and stopping to take a breather just ain't an option. I used to do this stuff all the time, not listen to my body when it was saying no more. You ruin your body that way. You aren't meant to push yourself that far that often.

Human is built to conserve energy so that their body always has some in store. Sure you can "get over that 40% wall" but it's not a feat of anykind. You feel like you want to stop because your brain tells you to keep some energy in store for further tasks. There is no point in evolution's point of view to waste all you have and then become helpless.  That being said, everyone who exercises seriously pushes themselves over that "40% wall" in regular basis and that's just fine as long as you don't injure yourself. Like I said, it's not a feat or some super saiyan mental state.

It's not really a good idea for ordinary people to use the 40% rule. Elite troops use it for survival. But the reason why our bodies don't use everything we have is because it is a sorta reserve fuel for dangerous situations. Not to be use on a day to day basis for fitness.

It's not your brain (as I assume you mean, ie. your physical computer) telling you that you can't do anymore, it's a collection of things, like fears, ego, self-image, and so on. This video has an interesting message, but here's an easier one:  When you think you can't run any longer, or can't do another push up or curl, etc. ... do 1-2 more and stop. If you are doing a bootcamp, or training and get to the end of your 8/10/12 reps... again do 1-2 more and stop. Tell yourself you can do it, make it happen and over time you will see how much more capable you are. It's a very simple and effective way to break one of our most omnipresent mental barriers.  The "voice" telling you that you cannot run any more is NOT a serious physical defense system, it's just your own bs getting in the way because you are doing something difficult and most of us have a fairly strong inclination to NOT stress ourselves, even when we specifically think we have set out to stress ourselves.  Special forces around the world use this basic technique to train their soldiers to find the extra energy and willpower they have, but do not know how to access. For most of us plebs, accessing another 60% is unrealistic and actually could be dangerous if we don't do it properly, but doing just a little more each time... that's relatively easy and it can have an incredible effect on how you live your life.

I agree with the little more each time and was not making a point against that.Â  There have been a few times in my life that IÂ  have pushed myself beyond total exhaustion and was astounded at my second wind, or hidden gas in the gas tank. I can also see doing this if you want to be a special forces killing machine, but not for a regular Joe who's looking to change his daily routine. My whole point is not pushing yourself past that point if you don't have to. I feel the intelligent thing to do is listen to your body and mind ques by not going to extremes. Great for inspiration. But there's a difference between pushing yourself and actually legit damaging your body. Honestly I see this video doing more harm than good. Navy SEAL's are the last example you should be giving people for advice on discipline, motivation and accomplishment... not when it comes as a general catch-all philosophy for anybody and everybody. Most people don't understand how the spec-ops approach is way more likely to be a giant detriment than a help.  I've loved studying all special forces for years, learning about tapping into super-human endurance and discipline (because I've had to); got massive respect for them. But this kind of approach only works for the minority alpha-male types who have unusually-high testosterone, healing abilities and exceptional biological mechanisms to compensate for damage.   Lots of people, including and especially me, had our own "40%" philosophy of refusing to acknowledge limits while always pushing them farther to make them extend further. I did this when I was 16-18 so I could be the best at Judo and Army Cadets and learn strength and confidence for all life's challenges. Always figured "If I really injure myself from pushing it too hard that'll suck, but I can handle the pain and that just means I'll be out of commission for weeks or months instead of days".  That thinking rings true for guys who turn into Rangers and NFL stars. For the rest of us - the literally tens of millions per year who thought the same - we ended up with crippling, permanent chronic pain that literally destroyed the rest of our entire lives. It's during those days of foolish youth that you don't realize that some body parts - like spinal disks made of cartilage - literally can't heal or regrow.  Most people, if they tried doing what he did finishing a marathon on feet full of broken bones, wouldn't just heal-up like a SEAL; instead they end up with severe osteoarthritis in their feet for the rest of their lives.

that mental barrier is there to protect the body from damage, many professional athletes also describe hitting a pain barrier when they work and then continue to push past that and the pain fades away. For the average person this is dangerous to do as it basically shuts down the protective barriers our brain has set up and go into survival mode but under watch (like with a professional coach who can see when too much  damage is going to happen) it does allows them to train harder, longer and achieve more in shorter time. Many soldiers are trained to push past this barrier because in combat situation their lives can depend on it and the price they pay in damage to their bodies is acceptable compared to not able to function in middle of battle.  Just remember there is a huge price to pay for going above this barrier regularly, it's only meant to be crossed in fight or flight scenarios that happens a few times in a life time. many professional athletes have burnt themselves out in their 30s and getting told they can never play their sport again.

Your beliefs are your reality. Many years ago I use to transport mentally challenged adults. There was this challenged individual called William who use toÂ have to step up on aÂ curb when he got off the bus to go inside the building. Everyone had to step up on this curb. After many months of thoughtlessly stepping up on the curb, 1 day William stopped at the curb. I said to him "come on William". His reply was "I can't. I kept trying to convince him he could but for that moment he didn't believe it. He just didn't believe he could. He would raise his foot up as if he wanted to but he just was convinced he couldn't.Â At that moment, his body was 100% capable but his mind was zero percentÂ believing. I finally held him by the arm and told him I would help him step up. That incident always stuck with me. That day I realized that we all have curbs in our life that we think we cant step up on simply because we believe we can't so we simply don't even try.

I'd say this is dangerous advice, as this might be good for a person who's too comfortable, but might be dangerous for another. Take me for example. I'm pretty good at my job. I make more when I work more. To get where I am, I worked my butt off, easily 60-75h/week for years of tough mental work, no holidays, 1 day weekends. I always kept pushing myself, always "do more, don't listen to your mind telling you you had enough." Wanna know what the result was? Severe burn-out syndrome, anxiety attacks, depression, took me a year to get back to lead at least a partially normal life and for my mind to recover. Your mind tells you that you had enough for a reason. Maybe you can get away with pushing yourself too hard 99 out of 100 times. But oh boy, does that 1 other time have potential to make your life so miserable, you wish you'd rather stayed lazy than this. I'm not saying be lazy, in case you are. I'm saying be careful, you only have 1 body and 1 mind and advice that might help one person might hurt another.

Why don't think big speakers do a bit of research on subjects before talking about it?  In a marathon when you hit "the wall" is not do to a metal "you can't do this" but a change in your bodies energy. The metal "wall" can be hit any time by anyone for any reason, but it is not the same as the "the wall" marathon runners hit. What happens at the wall is your body has depleted it carbohydrate reserves and you body now needs to get it's energy from fat and your body does not want to do this and does not do this instantly, so it almost feels like you body refuses to move and you need the metal toughness to keep going, then your body starts to actively convert fat stores in to energy.

I went out and camped the local sand dunes. Completely novice I over packed and under estimated the challenge ahead of me. On arrival I was told I'd have to hike past the tallest dune before I could camp. Not an easy feat when you're out of shape and dragging a full back country pack. Well I made it over the Dune and made a camp. I must have stopped 100 times up that Dune to rest. Tired and beaten I wanted to quit. I'd look at every recess in the sand and try to talk myself into 'just putting down there and no one would know'. But what got me over the dune was the thought of small progress. Walk 20 feet and rest. Then another 20 and rest. After that another 20 and maybe one more 20 before you finally make it.Afterwards I couldn't believe I had made it and since then it has remained a testament to myself over just how hard I can push myself.  Never doubt how far or how hard you can go.

Well, this is a nice rule for mental things, but I would not use it for physical things. There is a reason why your body complains if it is not used to heavy duty labor or exercise.  I can do about 20 push-ups all at once in one go. However, if I spread them out over the course of an entire day, I could do 600 (60 sets of 10 ). However those 600 are worthless and damaging when compared to the 20 all at once. It's been almost a year and my elbows still haven't fully recovered from that experiment. The muscles were so worn out that the bones themselves were doing the work, and that's just stupid and self damaging. By forcing yourself, you are essentially "cheating" and turning off your safety mechanisms.  The proof of my point is the fact that your Seal guy broke many bones in his foot and had kidney issues. Cause and effect.  Some things can impress me, like how Jack LaLanne could do 1000 push-ups in one go (but he was thoroughly used to exercising heavily and knew what he was doing, he worked up to that and knew enough to take breaks and not go to extremes - he did, after all, live to his late 90s with high quality of life)  But a guy who exercises and harms himself doesn't really impress me. There is a difference between impressive feats and fool-hardy feats.  However, since he is a type of soldier, he is expected (by his superiors) to go above and beyond for his country. In this case such extreme mental fortitude and lack of care for his own body is required. I don't think a video should be made out of it though, as the regular citizen should not be doing things like this. Better to start slow and SLOWLY increase the load until you can handle things like that without injury.

I do (something roughly like) this at the gym, and I go through very distinct phases. (I'm talking HIIT running here)... So, the first stage is pain and discomfort, then I hit the wall and push past it, then I go a bit numb and start to get runner's high. It feels great. Then usually, when my head is spinning, I'll move onto weights, and always do 'more than I can'. I get so high sometimes I start to hallucinate. It's at this point that I can literally do anything. I can run another 40 miles if you ask me too, because I'm so high, my mind is essentially completely detached. I'm not feeling any pain... or rather, some part of me is feeling pain, but it is as though 'I' am only experiencing that pain by proxy. As though the physical pain is being communicated to me via morse code, rather than me actually feeling it.   Of course some days I just can't even get past the first pain barrier, like if I'm depressed or just unmotivated. But it was really amazing to learn that there are whole other levels of consciousness beyond that first barrier, where a lot of 'newbies' think they've had enough and give up (and I was guilty of that too, a few years back). You aren't even close, and the best thing to do if you feel you've 'had enough' at 15 minutes or something, is to crank up the difficulty. Increase the speed, the incline, the resistance, whatever - you'll reach the wall faster, and the faster you get to the wall, the faster you get past it, and what lies beyond is amazing.

As an analogy to self-motivation, I think this is a fine idea.  You can go a little farther or push a little harder, and frequently you will be better for it.  Though that is just a very human approximation.  We don't know how to actually quantify what you're capable of, or where along the line you are at any given time.  It's not like the SeALs do a bunch of experiments and calculations to find out exactly how to make a number line and assign people spots on that line based on their full limits.  It is not scientific, it is a "Seat of your pants", spur of the moment type of idiom.  Going truly all out to 100% of what you're capable of could only mean death in the end, as you were no longer capable of doing something because you literally can't do anything anymore.  How do we determine we are 40% into an end result which logically should be death?  We can't.  There is no method of determining that sort of thing.  No "capability" quanta which we could divide up, assign proportional values to and turn into a number line.    So the important thing to remember from this is that you are capable of going beyond what you think you can do.  When you hit the limit, which is purely biological data as interpreted by your brain, which has been programmed through evolution to analyze your bodily systems and send signals telling you to stop or else you risk injury, you can go past that.  the 40% thing is banal woo.  It means nothing, it is just an arbitrary marker that once you hit it, you are capable of continuing.  40% is just a nice sounding round number implying you are capable of much much more.  The important thing there is that 40% is not 100%, as your brain and body might be telling you.  However, going to 100% is obviously a terrible idea, which is why we have that mental limit to begin with.  We're not gonna mate and pass on our genes if we don't have a self-governor and run or whatever til we die to stop that from happening.  So, listen to your body.  When you feel that arbitrary 40% parameter, you know you can go on.  Just know the soft limit is there for a reason, and decide for yourself if it is worth risking injury to continue.

+sean rodgers If you're a runner it makes sense.  I told myself something similar but not as extreme; I told myself that when I thought I could no longer go on I was only at 75% of my max.  Been running for 2 or 3 years now.  Nobody taught me this rule; it's just something I came up with based on my own experience.  Last year I worked up to a long of 15 miles.  Using my 75% rule some of my long runs fucking sucked, but I never hurt myself.  No over-use or impact injuries.  I chalk that up to strength training though, but the point remains, you can go further than your brain tells you.  Overcoming the barrier is empowering; each time you overcome it you push on to find it again, only to overcome it again.  This winter I'm focusing on strength training.  In spring I'll push on and see if I can work up to 20.  Then maybe 26 the next year.  Slow, gradual progress.  Keep pushing what you think is your limit.

The 40% rule is not the key to anything. It's just the knowledge that most people can do more. But they usually don't. The key is in adressing that in a multiple set of scenarios with different people, and not in some rich kid telling about how he did more push ups because a seal was in the room. Usually that is not the scenario.  Besides not going to a 100% is tied in with evolved adaptational responses. It very often makes sense to conserve energy to do the real job when needed. You'll notice most tribes don't do pushups. They work at survival using scarce resources and available energy wisely. It's not to say that the seal insights are not motivating and thought provoking - but on the other hand theirs is not an average, normal human existence and the task requirements are very different from the main stream. This assumption that all people have a massive physical will at their disposal at all times if they'd only focus is fallacious. So many other factors affect human performance, and what is an advantage in one context may very well be a strong disadvantage in another. Some people are so involved in their "sheer physical will" that they can't be properly relationally involved with other people, like say a family or an open community, or outside of a controlled environment.

Might as well be doing 100 pushups, 100 situps, 100 squats, and a 10 kilometer (6 mile) run. Every single day for 3 years.  There's giving it your all, then there's becoming disabled. Learn the difference. Turn off your pain receptors and sense of time and you'll know what I mean.
