From what i understand from a physiological sense if you apply this 40% rule to everything you do you will "fry" your nervous system. People who train past "pain barriers" on a consistent basis are looking for trouble. From what i understand adaption to a stimulus in the human body (and brain) is about "consistent" exposure not "intense" exposure. Example: Bulgarian weightlifters in their heyday- when exposed to weights in excess of 90% of 1rm CONSISTENTLY and GRADUALLY in waves would adapt and the nervous system reaction to this is that the body will lower the output of "stress" hormones as it get's "used to" lifting near maximal weights on a consistent basis.

There's 2 small problems with this approach that i can think of:  1. This technique doesn't rule out hazardous denial. Sure, you can probably push yourself beyond the limits you think you have...but at what cost? You mentioned that he damaged his kidneys and bones during the marathon, but he did it. There's a point where accomplishment exceeds the logic/need to do so. If he's planning on defusing a bomb at the end of the marathon and his livelihood is expendable for the lives of others, it might make sense...but sitting in a dialysis machine is a high price to pay for a ribbon/medal.  2. A big reason we don't push ourselves to do more is that we depend on other people being on the same page and at the same pace to assist us. You can burn through your paperwork in an hour at work with this technique...but it won't mean it'll be done because you still need other people to pick it up at their end. Taking this approach as a general rule in life means you look like and are perceived as a maniac who is potentially unstable because you push so hard when you don't need to AND it doesn't get everybody up to your speed. It also doesn't affect the turning of wheels that happen outside your control; you still need to wait for those things to get done before you can continue.

i think an important part is the "just a little bit more" mentality. now, i fucking hate running distances because, let's be honest, it sucks. in highschool i played lacrosse and we had to run 2 miles every day as a warmup, then had practice, then did sprints. one of the things that kept me going was that, when i was getting tired, i'd tell myself "comeon, just a little bit more. you can keep going to that tree" or "you can make it to the end of the block" and so on, and after i'd hit these mile markers, it was like i had forgotten about how shitty i had felt before them because i had made it. i gave myself time to celebrate the little victory of making it around the block and then, when i had lost that rush, i set my next milestone. i find myself using this same mentality with a lot of other things too. dont strive to improve yourself 100% overnight, because you'll just feel let-down and discouraged. however, if you can improve yourself by 10% or, hell, even 1% every day, you can celebrate that small victory and set the next milestone.

+ZIPPER978 war physically  destroys men. training for war requires a different approach compared to training, for example, basketball, or some other civilian pursuit. among other things, seal training serves the purpose of proving you meet minimum standards expected in a fighting force that must be able to complete missions in particularly extreme conditions. personal survival/ enrichment are not primary goals here. trying to follow the so called "40% rule" in anything other than a desperate situation is stupidity, unless you are actually a pussy, but if this is the case, the rule will not help you anyway, because 40% to you is really like 5-10%. actual physical limits exist for a reason, and exceeding them exacts a terrible price over time.

+vir Being in the military you are just a small number in the big scheme of things, where it's acceptable to lose a few. It makes sense to get as much productivity out of someone before they die. What is this level? Have to know it to apply it. I was stationed in the Sinai in the early 80's. Some days would climb to 135 degrees. One time they marched 50+ guys 100 miles non-stop to see how long it would take. I believe only one guy died, a couple sun strokes, many passed out from dehydration, (anything over about 120 degrees you can't drink enough water to stay hydrated).   Before being deployed to Grenada a group of us were told to empty our ruck sacks into our duffel bags and form a line. We went into an area with our empty rucks with all type of ammo stockpiled and told to take as much as we wanted. Normally, everyone is given a basic load to carry into combat, just enough to get you started. We figured they were probably testing this basic load somehow. Fortunately, I knew the less you carry the better off you are - some guys loaded up. Unfortunately, my duffel bag that had spare cloths and essentials never made the trip. Within a week and a half our uniforms were rotted and ripping to shreds. Guys were borrowing tee shirts and bandannas to use as loin clothes. They flew in replacement uniforms toward the end, around the morning before they flew the press in for photo ops, (god bless the press).  Because of this the military made sweeping changes to the uniforms that is still in effect today.  Personally, one of my essentials that didn't make the trip was my ear plugs. I'm now have a 20% service connected disability. I know what my limit is, but don't really need to know and wish I didn't.  I look at people that push themselves to the limit for fun about the same as someone that uses razor blades to self mutilate.

There is a reason why there is a ''wall". I was only able to do about 10 pull ups at a time. My staff Sergeant wanted me to do 40. I done 16 at one time with those rubberband things that are supposed assist you. I probably did 60 that day. After I was done I didn't realize that I torn my muscles to near permanent damage. When I woke up the next day there were painful bulges of what used to be muscle sticking out of my back. I had my brother try to massage them out. It was too painful. After that I was only able to do 2 pull ups at one time. I didn't improve for months. There is a reason why your mind wants you to stop when you get tired or start to feel pain. It is called self preservation.

It's a shame to promote effort so much without talking about the limits of humans. There is such a thing as over-training, pushing your limits can get you hurt very easily. Like that guy apparently was, and you don't want that for your health. If you hit a wall at 40 % it's for a reason, after that your chances of getting hurt is significantly higher. With proper training, stretching, you can push after 40 %, relatively safely. However there is a point where you MUST know to stop. I'd say 70 or 80 % for an athlete's training, probably 45 % for anyone untrained in the sport or movement he/she is doing. Your body CAN do it, but it doesn't mean it SHOULD do it. You might feel like a bad-ass but you'll just feel bad after.

+sidewinder2057 I'm currently reading the book Once A Runner by John L. Parker Jr.  In one part of it, the main guy, an elite level runner, is relaxing with his girlfriend.  Him and her are sleeping together in the bed.  She wakes up because of the beating of his heart; thinking something is wrong she wakes him up.  He assures her that there is nothing wrong.  When I'm in running condition I have similar things happen.  I can hear and feel my heartbeat when I'm relaxing.  I'm no elite level runner, I assure you.  My long runs last year worked up to about 2.5 hours.  After the first 10 minutes or so my heart rate will work up to 140-180 depending on the intensity of the run.  As long as there are no irregularities, and you are not overreaching on your training, there is nothing dangerous about this as long as you are taking care of your body between training sessions. +hawaiidispenser The mentality displayed here is appealing to me, but I have gone through injury exactly because of it. About a year ago, I did exactly the same thing with pullups that is being described here. I did pullups until failure, and then I continually rested for a little while and did just one more; again and again. It's uncanny how similar this situation is to what I did.  The end result though, was quite different for me: golfer's elbow and severe pain. Something inside went "pop" and a terribly unnatural feeling went through me. I knew I had hurt myself in a very stupid way. My body just wasn't at the point where it was ready to reach such levels. +BunnaySango it's a balancing act. Initially we're so far into a comfort oriented life that following something like this can help push us up to our natural limits. But conversely we need to be wise enough to know when it's actually not worth it to push. It takes will power in both directions. Notice when the guy this video is about finished the initial race he had broken several bones in his foot and gotten kidney damage. Is that anyone's goal when it comes to running? Those things have lasting affects on people. Broken bones don't always heal properly, I have several I can personally attest to. Kidney damage can be lasting and can cause you to improperly filter your blood in the future and can lead to issues with urinary infections, vomiting, nausea and other life-long problems. I myself ruined several tendons in my foot doing the exact same shit. I couldn't walk for 4 months because I thought I was being a pussy when my brain was telling me to stop running. It was right. This motto is for getting you out of a comfort zone. But when your comfort zone switches to a place of discomfort a motto like this isn't always so helpful. Rehabbing my foot was horrible, and I can't really run more than 5 miles in one sitting now because the tendons are still weak, but I'm thankful for that 5 miles, things could be a lot worse. Doc says that maybe in a year they might be strong enough for me to finish a marathon but I'm not going to rush it. Physical fitness isn't always about crushing all of your goals. It's about patience as well, and sometimes we need to have patience and realize that simply improving upon yesterday's results is sometimes enough, even if we still haven't reached our goals. We all have long lives ahead of us barring freak incidents, we should train like we're going to be alive for a long time. The last thing you want to do is give yourself long-lasting, permanent disabilities or injuries.

I used to go to a kickboxing club, with a huge push through it mantra. After being in-between 2 6 foot+ guys who had been doing kickboxing for years in a circle kicking as hard as we could the pads of the person to our left 50 times and than to our right 50 times and one more 50 to our left my right shoulder was destroyed.   I felt something pop it was kind of painful but you know what I pushed through it and did sparring afterwards because the pain went away and just felt numb. It took 2 Fking years to heal and over $4,000 in physio and was during the first two years of university. Working out at my own pace I got a nice amount of muscle and have maintained it since, if anyone tells you to push through it to get more gains... tell them to F off.   Slow and steady wins the race, you can't go up in weight forever at some point you have to plateau. So many people have stories similar to mine. Take your time and build strength and go at a steady consistent pace.  Having an average joe do over 100 pull ups accomplished nothing and I bet he messed up his arms for the next week.  He'd of gotten a better result doing 10-15 pull ups daily for that same week and then progressing in higher reps or attaching weights to his legs. Making people hate working out is why 90% or more of you don't work out.

Bas Haren Yes, as I have said, there is such a thing as over-training but the general public is hardly able to do it. By asking people to push beyond their limits, you ask otherwise sedentary and inactive people to do the base minimum they require. When training children in gymnastics who haven't done many activities, a little motivation can go a long way in convincing kids they can go farther than they think they can.  We naturally put limits on ourselves mentally that aren't necessary. If you are not used to breaking through that first layer of "I want to quit now" you will never get better. I like to think of it like levels.  Level 1: Heart rate increases Level 2: Breaking a sweat Level 3: Tired Level 4: Would really like a break right now Level 5: Holy crap this is insane Level 6: I didn't think I could go this far! Level 7: Injury becomes a real possibility Level 8: Okay you should really stop now Level 9: What the hell are you doing? Stop. Level 10: Death  Most people stop at Level 2 or 3 when you should really be going to level 4 or 5. If you are an athlete and wish to improve, you should occasionally get to 6 or even 7 if you have set goals and know the risks. Very few have the conviction and will to even make it to 8.

I have read before (sorry I don't remember where so take this with a grain of salt) that the human body can heal from injuries while our muscular system is at full function. Animals experience nasty tears and muscle injuries in nature every day like us and there have been many documented cases of animals that had their legs ran over by car, fell a large distance and injured multiple muscle groups etc. and healed completely while continuously limping around every day all day. They don't sit down and use ice and wait around. Our bodies can heal from injuries much faster when we constantly supply the area with fresh blood. So injuries aren't as crippling as we make them to be.  There are of course compound fractures and other injuries that might spell doom for normal rehab but I am just referring to muscle, ligament, and tendon injuries. Remember I am not preaching this as a 100% truth or anything. I just remembered it after reading this thread and thought someone might know more about it or even debunk it.

Brittin Frielink Good on you for not preaching the "TRUTH". I kinda seem like i do that when i talk but don't worry i consider the possibility that i'm wrong whenever i say anything. I follow a vet channel named VetRanch, this channel takes medical care of injured, sick and contaminated animals.  Recovery and musle tear, fracture and open wounds is the norm. so i've seen a bit of that. So while it is true by my understanding that blood flow and inflammation is the first step of recovery, followed by duplication of the cells and reconstruction, the body is a mechanical construction; Each thing more or less has its place, and if it's displaced or diformed, trouble arise. Animals will heal from terrible wounds, but they become weaker, their bones not connecting, their legs, limping.  For proper reconstruction and healing, surgery is often necessary after important trauma. For small inflammations, superfical cuts, and the like, no need to baby yourself too much, desinfect the area, but don't take anti-inflammatory, they prevent the body's natural healing process. As an example of fracute and healing, i've broken my left pinky. Yeah i know poor me, however because i didn't know better, i wanted to continue lifting weights. After not enough time had passed.  Because of this my finger healed twisted somewhat and the joint isn't as smooth as it should be.  So what's the take away from that ? To grow strong you have to break and tear the muscle fibers, creating inflammation somewhat which triggers the improvement and thickening of the muscle cells. However ligament and tendon injuries (not inflammation mind you) are only fixed by surgery. Even tendonites, which is tendon inflammation can be extremely painful and debilitating.  TL;DR : TRAIN SMART NOT HURT.

I said fuck that and met up with personal trainers and martial artists in my area and they said I am going to be just fine. In fact, they were so unmoved by my story that I knew I was not very educated about how the body works.They took me in and showed me that my mind was weak at that time and that I had given up. Initially when I started my rehabilitation the pain was excruciating and I couldn't sleep but each day I realized that if it weren't for these guys pushing me harder I would still be whining on the couch. Years have passed and I am training harder now than I have ever trained before. I train smart and have never had any problems since. I think a huge part (not all) of my past problem and many others still today, stems from training with bad form, training like a weekend warrior,  and shying away from the thought of another injury.  The story about my uncle is just his personal story. He kept reinjuring himself and was forced to quit. That is his own fault for not pushing himself as I have.

yes. that actually is why our bodies can do that. there is a safety limit. think about a machine with a safety limit. e.g. the weight limit in an elevator. you CAN go above that. maybe even a lot above that. but it is a SAFETY LIMIT and not made for "everyday life", because the probability of failure increases a lot past this point. our bodies are able to accomplish astonishing things in emergency situations. as in, life-or-death situations. to try to "apply it to our daily lives" (03:55) is the recipe for some kind of burn out or body failure.

That maybe true but that kind of thinking gets you nowhere, you gotta always push your limits , go through pain if you wanna get where you're trying to get. If every time your body feels uncomfortable and you feel a little pain you stop you'll be a sorry ass quitter.  "Only those who risk going too far, can know how far one can possibly go."

There is a lot of difference between 'a little pain' and damaging your body beyond repair. Of course you need to leave the comfort zone and endure discomfort in order to achieve anything, thats life. But being uncomfortable is not the same as needlessly using up your bodies emergency reserves, especially not if you do so on a regluar basis. By the way, pain is a warning sign of you body that there is damage. Ignoring that and going on with what is painful requires a very sensible approach in order to avoid lasting damage. There is a very thin line between enduring 'a little pain' and hurting yourself. Especially when you are taking pain relievers, as many athletes do nowadays.
